title: Swamp Thing (song)
text:
"Swamp Thing" is a song by British music group <a href="the%20Grid">the Grid</a>. It was released on 23 May 1994 as a single and is included on the Grid's third album, "<a href="Evolver%20%28The%20Grid%20album%29">Evolver</a>" (1994). It peaked at number three on the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK</a>, <a href="ARIA%20Charts">Australian</a>, and <a href="IFPI%20Danmark">Danish</a> singles charts and reached the top five in an additional seven countries, including Finland and Norway, where it reached number two. The song was later sampled in "<a href="Banjo%20Thing">Banjo Thing</a>" by <a href="Infernal%20%28Danish%20band%29">Infernal</a> and "Swamp Thing" by <a href="Pegboard%20Nerds">Pegboard Nerds</a>. "<a href="NME">NME</a>" magazine ranked it number 41 in their list of the 50 best songs of 1994.
Content.
"Swamp Thing" is almost completely instrumental, consisting mainly of: <a href="Drum%20kit">drums</a>, <a href="synthesizer">synthesizer</a> sounds and <a href="banjo">banjo</a>. The only vocals are "Well alright, watch out", "Feel alright" and "I just dig it", sampled from the 1973 <a href="reggae">reggae</a> song "Papa Do It Sweet" by Lloyd & Patsy. The banjo part was written and performed by Roger Dinsdale – a folk musician who also played the <a href="guitar">guitar</a> and the <a href="mandolin">mandolin</a>. Dinsdale died in July 2009.
Critical reception.
Music writer <a href="James%20Masterton">James Masterton</a> wrote in his weekly UK chart commentary, "I can detect a theme developing here over who can make the best dance record out of the silliest original idea. As if <a href="Doop%20%28band%29">Doop</a> wasn't bad enough we now have the <a href="The%20Grid">Grid</a> moving away from <a href="ambient%20dub">ambient dub</a> and scoring their biggest hit ever with a dance track based on a <a href="banjo">banjo</a> reel." He added that it "actually is quite inspired". Andy Beevers from "<a href="Music%20Week">Music Week</a>"'s "RM" Dance Update commented, "Part Two of the Grid's US travelogue takes us east from <a href="Texas">Texas</a> [with their 1993 single "Texas Cowboys"] to the Deep South, where they successfully set frantic banjo picking against uptempo <a href="House%20music">house</a> beats to create a high energy hoe down." He also declared it as "a mad banjo and house hybrid [that] works surprisingly well." Another editor, <a href="James%20Hamilton%20%28DJ%20and%20journalist%29">James Hamilton</a> described it as "a breezy progressive throbber."
Chart performance.
"Swamp Thing" was very successful on the charts across several continents. In Europe, it soared to number two in Finland, Norway and Scotland. It was a top-10 hit also in Austria, Belgium, Denmark (number three), Iceland, Ireland, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. On the <a href="Eurochart%20Hot%20100">Eurochart Hot 100</a>, it hit number four. In the UK, the single peaked at number three in its fifth week on the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a>, on 26 June. It also reached number-one on "<a href="Music%20Week">Music Week</a>"'s <a href="UK%20Dance%20Singles%20Chart">Dance Singles</a> chart. Additionally, it was a top-20 hit in Germany and a top-50 hit in France. Outside Europe, "Swamp Thing" reached number three in Australia as well as on the "<a href="RPM%20%28magazine%29">RPM</a>" Dance/Urban chart in Canada. It also peaked at number 41 in New Zealand. The single was awarded with a <a href="Music%20recording%20certification">silver record</a> in the UK with a sale of 200,000 copies and a <a href="Music%20recording%20certification">platinum record</a> in Australia, after 70,000 units were sold.
Music video.
"Swamp Thing" was accompanied by a <a href="music%20video">music video</a>. The video switches back and forth between two scenes: <a href="computer-generated%20imagery">computer-generated imagery</a> of a group of <a href="robot">robot</a>s dancing to a techno beat and a blank white landscape with a crawling <a href="Infant">baby</a> and music synthesiser instruments. The scene with the baby and the instruments also inspired the "Evolver" album cover art.
